Title: Bitcoin Wins the Quarter. Energy and Japan Funds Also Scored Big.
Summary: Do the investors in the new Bitcoin exchange-traded funds launched this past quarter know they’re buying a product that produces no cash flow, has no physical reality, and was invented by Satoshi Nakamoto, a pseudonymous person or entity whose true identity remains unknown?  In January, just two months after crypto bro Sam Bankman-Fried was convicted of committing one of the biggest frauds in Wall Street history, regulators approved 11 cryptocurrency ETFs after a decade of lobbying by Wall Street, greenlighting more later.  In the blink of an eye, some nine new ETFs that subsequently launched have gathered $34 billion in assets.

Title: Taiwanese Chip-Making Giant TSMC Says No Earthquake Damage to Most-Critical Tools
Summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, the world’s largest contract chip maker, said an earthquake on Wednesday put a small number of its manufacturing tools out of commission but that its most critical machinery had been spared damage.  + The company, known by its initials TSMC, said that it evacuated workers from some of its chip-making plants after the earthquake and suspended work on construction sites.  + As of Thursday, though, it said construction work resumed following inspections and that employees were back at work shortly after the quake, the most severe in Taiwan in 25 years.

Title: Nvidia supplier SK Hynix to invest $3.87 billion in US chip packaging plant
Summary: SK Hynix, the world's second-largest memory chip maker, said on Wednesday it will invest around $3.87 billion to build an advanced packaging plant and research and development facility for AI products in the U.S. state of Indiana.  The new plant will include an advanced chip production line to mass-produce next-generation high bandwidth memory (HBM) chips, currently used in graphic processing units that train artificial intelligence systems, the Nvidia supplier said in a statement.  Mass production is planned to start in the second half of 2028.

Title: Tech stocks: The three 'horses' to bet on in tightening AI race
Summary: In the year's transition from the first quarter to the second quarter, is 2024 shaping up to be another breakout year for tech as far as AI catalysts are concerned? Public Ventures President and Chief Market Strategist Lou Basenese joins Yahoo Finance in-studio to talk about tech stock leaders with broadening use cases for artificial intelligence, highlighting Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT), and Apple (AAPL) "You have to play a basket. You're not going to be able to pick a single horse in this AI race and work out as well as it did for Nvidia (NVDA) last year," Basenese says. "Let's just face it, Nvidia can't have the same run... this year as it did last year. It just would become too big of a company."
